text: hey everybody
thomas joseph here with another kitchen
conundrum i know you've been asking
about
have you tried melting chocolate for a
candy or cookie project that you're
working on and you end up with a dull
white sheen on top of your chocolate
like this well what this is is the fat
within the cocoa butter it rises to the
surface if it's melted improperly and
today i'm going to show you how to fix
that
by tempering your chocolate tempering
chocolate is a really interesting
process but slowly bringing chocolate up
to a higher temperature reducing the
temperature and cooling the chocolate
and then bringing it up again and what
that does is it leaves you with a
wonderful shiny chocolate that's perfect
for barks for candies for dipping
cookies in and it also has a really nice
texture and it's not that hard to do you
just need to know that temperatures for
the chocolate that you're using so today
I'm using milk chocolate for my holiday
bark what you need is a pound and a half
of chocolate in total I'm going to show
you a tempering method that's called
seeding and you want to make sure when
you're melting chocolate for any project
that the pieces are uniform in size so
that they melt at an even rate I have
one and a quarter pounds of chocolate
here and I need a quarter pound more but
this needs to be left in one big piece
so we need another piece of chocolate
that's 4 ounces and this is perfect here
so reserve this piece off to the side
and now we're going to melt the
chocolate and for this I'm using milk
chocolate today I need to bring this up
to 113 degrees so we're going to take
the pound and a quarter of chocolate and
I'm going over a pot of simmering water
and it turned off the water because you
don't want boiling you don't want steam
any moisture that you introduce into
your chocolate will make your chocolate
C's so be careful not to introduce any
moisture here and what I'm going to do
is just gently stir every so often until
the chocolate is melted and I want this
mixture to come up to a hundred and
thirteen degrees
and that's specific to milk chocolate
now for bittersweet it's about 118
degrees but when you're tempering
chocolate whichever brand you're using
go on their website and see what they
recommend for temperatures the chocolate
is completely melted there are no pieces
and I'm using a digital thermometer here
in the middle of the chocolate avoiding
the bottom of the bowl and I need a
temperature of 113 you want to make sure
when you're doing this process for any
chocolate that you never go over 130
degrees because you will scorch your
chocolate so I'm at 110 right now I'm
going to keep stirring until it reaches
113 degrees our chocolate is at 113
degrees I'm going to take it off the
heat onto a towel to catch any of that
excess moisture and now to bring the
temperature of the chocolate down I
needed to come down to about 81 degrees
for milk chocolate for this brand that
I'm using and I'm going to take that
quarter pound piece that I had before
and I'm going to place it in the bowl
stirring constantly and what this does
is it acts as almost like an ice cube
and bringing the temperature of the
chocolate down now you don't want to add
chopped chocolate here because what that
does is it brings it down to rapidly
this is a nice slow way of doing so and
this method here is called seeding so
it's been about 20 minutes of stirring
and I'm going to check the temperature
and it should be 81 degrees which it is
so that's great now if you still have a
piece of chocolate left fish that out
and now what we have to do is we have to
bring this chocolate up again in
temperature so it's 86 to 88 degrees for
milk chocolate and if you were using a
bittersweet chocolate it would be 88 to
90 degrees so I'm going to turn off my
simmering water I'm going to place the
bowl over the heat and this goes up to
about 86 degrees 86 degrees so that's
good and now immediately take the bowl
off the heat I like to again place it
directly on top of a terry cloth towel
something that will absorb the
condensation on the outside of the bowl
and now if you're using this to make a
holiday bark you can immediately pour it
into the pan or if you're dipping
cookies or dried fruits into your
wonderful tempered chocolate you could
use an electric heating pad to keep it
warm warm enough so that you can dip in
and it doesn't cool down too quickly so
I'm going to use this immediately I'm
going to pour it right into a baking
sheet here lined with parchment and
working quickly you want to use an
offset spatula and just gently spread
your tempered chocolate in a nice thin
even layer and now you can use I'm going
to use peppermint candies today but you
could use pistachios any sort of nut can
go on top of your dried fruits embellish
this however you'd like so this needs to
sit at room temperature until it's
completely firm and you're able to crack
it into nice wonderful pieces our
chocolate is nice and firm I'm going to
lift the sides of the parchment up and
it should pop right out and now I can
break this into wonderful sized pieces
and you can see the top of the chocolate
is nice and shiny
I think bigger is better don't be too
skimpy with those portions this is a
really great gift and there you go your
chocolate is now going to look as good
as it tastes and
you're bloom chocolate conundrum is now
solved with tempering chocolate how easy
was that
enjoy
